stem: The charge nurse is reviewing the following actions taken by the registered nurse (RN). Indicate which actions require intervention by the charge nurse by selecting them.

itemContext.sbar:
S: Jameson Riley, a 58-year-old male with a T4 spinal cord injury, was admitted yesterday for management of recurrent autonomic dysreflexia. At 07:30, he reported a severe headache and blurred vision. His blood pressure was 210/110 mmHg, and heart rate was 52 bpm.

A: The patient has a history of neurogenic bowel, with his last bowel movement three days ago. He typically manages this at home using a bisacodyl suppository every other day. He is currently experiencing an episode of autonomic dysreflexia, likely triggered by bowel or bladder distention.

B: Mr. Riley sustained his spinal cord injury at T4 ten years ago. He understands his condition and usually manages his bowel regimen independently at home. He has been compliant with his medications and bowel program prior to this admission.

O: Currently, the patient is restless and diaphoretic. A Foley catheter is in place, draining clear yellow urine. Vital signs at 07:30: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air, Temp 99.1°F (37.3°C). Orders include PRN hydralazine 10 mg IVP for SBP > 180 mmHg and digital rectal exam PRN for impaction. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO q4h PRN for headache. Current time is 07:45. The patient requires immediate intervention to address the autonomic dysreflexia episode.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, BUN: 22 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL, WBC: 8.5 x 10^3/uL, RBC: 4.8 x 10^6/uL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Docusate sodium 100 mg PO daily, Bisacodyl suppository PR qod. PRN: Hydralazine 10 mg IVP for SBP > 180 mmHg, Acetaminophen 650 mg PO q4h PRN for headache.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 07:30: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air, Temp 99.1°F (37.3°C). 07:00: BP 150/90 mmHg, HR 68 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 97% on room air, Temp 98.6°F (37°C).

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Administering hydralazine IVP is appropriate given the patient's elevated blood pressure (SBP > 180 mmHg) as per the PRN order. Checking the Foley catheter for kinks or obstructions is a critical initial step to rule out urinary retention as a cause of autonomic dysreflexia. Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower the blood pressure and reduce the severity of the headache. Contacting the physician is necessary if initial interventions are ineffective or if the patient's condition worsens despite treatment. Loosening restrictive clothing is crucial to reduce external stimuli that can exacerbate autonomic dysreflexia.
rationale.incorrect: Performing a digital rectal exam without first addressing other potential causes or administering medication could worsen the patient's condition and further elevate blood pressure. Digital rectal exams should be performed cautiously and only after other causes have been ruled out or treated. Administering acetaminophen is not the priority action because it does not directly address the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia. Acetaminophen is for headache, a symptom, but not the primary problem.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention.
Always assess and address the most common causes first: bladder, bowel, skin.
Elevate the head of the bed to reduce blood pressure during an autonomic dysreflexia episode.

questionTrap.trap: The question focuses on prioritizing actions, so test-takers might be tempted to select actions that seem helpful but are not the most immediate or critical for managing autonomic dysreflexia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and identify the actions that directly address the life-threatening symptoms and underlying causes of autonomic dysreflexia.

mnemonic.title: S.C.I.P
mnemonic.expansion: S: Search for the cause. C: Check catheter & bladder. I: Initiate BP control (Hydralazine). P: Position (Elevate HOB).

options.text: Administer hydralazine 10 mg IVP per order.
options.feedback: Correct. Hydralazine will lower the blood pressure.

options.text: Perform a digital rectal exam to assess for impaction.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This can exacerbate the condition. Medicate first.

options.text: Administer acetaminophen 650 mg PO for headache.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Addresses the symptom, not the cause.

options.text: Check the Foley catheter for kinks or obstructions.
options.feedback: Correct. Check for and relieve urinary retention.

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 45 degrees.
options.feedback: Correct. This will help to lower the blood pressure.

options.text: Contact the physician to report the patient's condition.
options.feedback: Correct. Important to keep the physician informed.

options.text: Loosen any restrictive clothing on the patient.
